source.title: 1.	Collection and Preservation of Samples + PDMPO

source.description: Select polycarbonate filter size based on your diatom/community.

source.body: (ex. 0.22mm to collect all potential diatoms from an environmental sample, or 2.0 mm to collect diatoms from axenic cultures).

source.title: 1.	Collection and Preservation of Samples + PDMPO

source.description: Either process samples immediately or preserve to process later. Proceed for processing.

source.body: Samples can be processed immediately (described in the following text) or preserved to be processed later. In the event of one collecting samples over the course of a time series for later comparison, preserving the samples is highly recommended for accurate comparison. It is important to process all samples at the same time in the same conditions when you are hoping to compare them (ex. Process all treatments at the same time, or if this is not feasible prices all replicates per treatment at the same time).

source.title: 1.	Collection and Preservation of Samples + PDMPO

source.description: the vacuum Filter designated volume onto the filter.

source.body:
It is advised to filter all replicates in a corresponding treatment simultaneously to minimize the chances of error amongst your replicates. Once filtered, turn off the vacuum, release the vacuum pressure.
Volume is based on the initial volume of your cultures and biomass (i.e. Whether you are using 50 mL culture tubes vs. 250 mL culture flasks, or based on diatom concentration or biomass concentration).
Previous experiments have been performed filtering 10 mL of culture to 100 mL of culture.
The later-described fluorometer calibration procedure and formation of a standard curve will adjust the sensitivity of the equipment, allowing for accurate measurements of incorporated PDMPO dye, regardless of the sample volume filtered.

source.title: 1.	Collection and Preservation of Samples + PDMPO

source.description:
Add
volume onto the filters using sterile growth media if they are cultures.
OR 0.22 mm filtered sample water for environmental samples.

source.body: This step is crucial as it washes away any leftover external PDMPO from the cells which will interfere with your later calculations. It is best to turn the vacuum off before adding the volume to ensure the cells on the filter receive equal volumes of media/rinsing.

source.title: 1.	Collection and Preservation of Samples + PDMPO

source.description: After adding volume to all replicates, turn the vacuum on and filter volume through for rinse 1.

source.body: Ensure no liquid remains around the internal lid of the filter tulip, as this will dilute the next step.

source.description: Turn the vacuum off and release any built-up pressure from the filter rig.

Add
of 10% HCl onto the filters and incubate for
.
Turn vacuum on and filter through.
Leave vacuum on and rinse the internal lip of the filter tulip with Milli-Q water to ensure the remaining acid is removed from the tulip prior to the next step.

source.body: This is of critical importance as even the smallest amount of 10% HCl remaining has the potential to prevent the osmotic lysing of the cells via the Milli-Q incubation.

source.description: When acid is completely removed with the Milli-Q wash, turn vacuum off and release pressure.

Add
Milli-Q (resistivity of greater than or equal to 18 Ω-cm).

source.body: These two incubation steps osmotically lyse the diatom cells and effectively release PDMPO taken up by the diatoms and stored in the silica deposition vesicle, but not yet incorporated into the frustule. Failure to lyse the cells will result in potential large standards of error amongst replicates and inaccurate deposition rate calculations.

source.description:
Incubate for
.
Turn vacuum on until all Milli-Q has been pulled through.
Turn vacuum off.

Perform one final rinse of
sterile media or filtered environmental water, ensuring the filters are equally covered by liquid.
Using sterile tweezers, fold filters into quarters and place in labeled 2 mL cryovial.

Flash freeze in liquid nitrogen immediately after sampling, then store at
until processing.

Frustule digestion is necessary for accurate results and if the frustule digestion is not properly performed, there is a high likelihood of significant error among replicates.
Further detail on frustule digestion can be found in LeBlanc and Hutchins 2005.

Thaw samples on ice and prepare 1L stocks of
and
.
Once samples are thawed, carefully remove filters from cryovials and transfer to 15 mL labeled Falcon tubes.

Add
volume of
to all tubes.
Ensure filters are fully submerged in the solution.
Mix gently by hand to remove any air bubbles around filter.

Place tubes in a rack in an
water bath for
incubation in the dark.

Remove tubes from water bath and cool in ice bath for
.

Once cooled, add
of
to each tube, resulting in a net volume of
.

source.body: At this point, the frustules of the diatoms should be digested and the only source of PDMPO fluorescence will stem from the PDMPO that has been deposited into the frustule itself via deposition.

source.description: Invert tubes and hand mix thoroughly.

source.body: It is normal for filter to degrade during the hot NaOH digestion.

source.description:
Centrifuge tubes at
for
prior to reading fluorescence of the matrix.

source.body: Centrifuge to ensure filter fragments/remaining cells are not interfering with fluorescence measurements.

source.description: Turn vacuum on until media or environmental water has been pulled through.
Turn vacuum off.
Screw Falcon tube lids on to prevent evaporation during incubation.

Critical Step for Reading Sample protocol
Establishing a Standard Curve: Prior to centrifuging samples for reading, establish a standard curve of 5 different concentrations. Standard curve replicates are to be:
-
that has been incubated at
in the hot water bath along with the other samples.
- Chilled on ice and neutralized with +
with selected volume of PDMPO then added prior to reading.
- Ensure there is a blank, consisting only of the NaOH-HCl matrix with no PDMPO addition.

{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aaf3m","text":"Information can be graphed to show silica deposition rates over time.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]}

description: This method can be used to assess and quantify the rate of silica deposition (bSi) over time in diatoms to determine their rate of frustule synthesis. This protocol has been adapted for the processing of both cultures as well as environmental samples when inoculated with PDMPO [2‐(4‐pyridyl)‐5‐((4‐(2dimethylaminoethylaminocarbamoyl)methoxy)phenyl)oxazole], which is a fluorescent dye that is co-deposited with silica during frustule biosynthesis in a 3230:1 Si:PDMPO (mol:mol) ratio.
